Referrals.title: What Others Say About Me
Referrals.subtitle: Discover how my colleagues and mentors describe working with me—insights into my dedication, creativity, and ability to drive impactful collaboration.
Referrals.ethanReferral1: I've had the privilege of working alongside Bobby, and I can confidently say he is one of the best teammates I have ever had. His commitment to excellence is unmatched. He takes extreme ownership of every project he touches, ensuring not just success but continuous improvement.
Referrals.ethanReferral2: Bobby strikes the perfect balance between working hard and keeping things fun. He is one of the most productive engineers I have worked with, yet he also brings an energy that makes collaboration enjoyable. Beyond his technical skills, Bobby genuinely cares about his work and his coworkers, always looking for ways to support the team.
Referrals.ethanReferral3: He is also constantly exploring new technologies to enhance efficiency and elevate our product. His curiosity and drive make him an invaluable asset to any team.
Referrals.adamReferral1: Bobby is an exceptional software engineer, and I learned a great deal from his expertise and problem-solving abilities. As the QA Engineer on his team, I often worked closely with him to troubleshoot and resolve issues.
Referrals.adamReferral2: From day one, Bobby's technical skills were evident. He not only developed complex systems but also took the time to ensure those systems were built with scalability, performance, and maintainability in mind. His attention to detail and ability to write clean, efficient code made him an invaluable asset to our team.
Referrals.adamReferral3: What truly stood out about Bobby was his collaborative nature. He was always open to feedback, quick to address concerns, and incredibly patient when helping me understand the technical intricacies of the features we were testing. Bobby's ability to communicate complex technical concepts in a clear and approachable manner made him a pleasure to work with, especially when debugging or fine-tuning code.
Referrals.adamReferral4: Beyond his technical acumen, Bobby's positive attitude and professionalism were infectious. He consistently contributed to a positive team dynamic and worked tirelessly to meet deadlines while maintaining high-quality standards. His leadership and ability to mentor junior engineers were also noteworthy, as he guided the team with both technical knowledge and a supportive attitude.
Referrals.adamReferral5: I have no doubt that Bobby will continue to excel in his career at Opendorse, and I would highly recommend him to anyone seeking a skilled, dependable, and innovative software engineer. It was an absolute privilege to work alongside him, and I look forward to seeing all that he accomplishes in the future.
Referrals.santiReferral1: Bobby is the rare combination of talent, hard work, and a desire to grow.
Referrals.santiReferral2: He tackled hard and complex problems for our team, produced a high amount of work every single sprint without sacrificing quality, and challenged himself to grow in and out of work by learning new technologies and working on personal projects.
Referrals.santiReferral3: Bobby will thrive in an environment with high expectations where he will be continuously challenged to to grow.
Referrals.steveReferral1: I was Bobby's manager for three years at Opendorse. I could share for hours all the things about Bobby that I admire but I'll do my best to highlight the most important characteristics here. Bobby is outright just a fun guy to work with and be around. He has a great sense of humor that is paired with a hard work ethic.
Referrals.steveReferral2: Bobby was always my leader for getting a ton work done, on time and at a high quality. He set the standard for our coding teams often completing his sprint work early and looking for side projects to push the team forward. One example that comes to mind is introducing our React developers to TypeScript and leading the charge to modernize our front-end languages. On top of that, he is great mentor and teacher for junior engineers. He prioritized their development as engineers just as much as his own and I always appreciated that about Bobby.
Referrals.steveReferral3: What sets Bobby apart from other engineers is how he finds joy in the moment. He has a great sense of humor and positivity that he relies on as a North Star when work gets hard. I can recount a number of meetings where he had us all rolling on the floor laughing instead of us being anxious over tight deadlines. This attitude is critical for successful teams and its something you'll get when you work with Bobby.

EngineeringPhilosophy.title: My Engineering Philosophy
EngineeringPhilosophy.subtitle: Engineering with empathy, efficiency, and thoughtful automation—because great software isn't just about shipping features; it's about empowering the people who build them.
EngineeringPhilosophy.radicalEmpathyDescription: I foster trust through open communication, making it safe to ask questions, raise concerns, and collaborate deeply.
EngineeringPhilosophy.developerExperienceDescription: Efficient tools and workflows minimize wasted time, boost morale, and let engineers focus on meaningful work.
EngineeringPhilosophy.ownershipWithGenerosityDescription: When something breaks, we fix it together—no finger-pointing. Sharing credit and lessons strengthens the whole team.
EngineeringPhilosophy.technicalForesightDescription: Well-designed guardrails and flexible architecture allow growth without accumulating tomorrow's tech debt.
EngineeringPhilosophy.relentlessAutomationDescription: Automate the boring, enforce standards in CI/CD pipelines, and let humans innovate where it matters most.
EngineeringPhilosophy.transparentCommunicationDescription: Frequent, open updates keep teams aligned. More clarity upfront prevents fire drills later.
EngineeringPhilosophy.mentorshipDescription: A mentor's success is measured by their mentees' growth. Empower peers to speak up, challenge ideas, and own their craft.
EngineeringPhilosophy.kindnessDescription: Feedback should guide, not criticize. Code reviews are for team growth, not personal attacks.

PreferredTechStack.title: Tech Stack I Love Working With
PreferredTechStack.subtitle: Technologies I prefer and frequently use in my projects.
PreferredTechStack.reactDescription: I enjoy React for its flexibility—whether building simple components or architecting complex applications, it adapts to the project's needs. Its component-based approach and rich ecosystem make it one of my favorite front-end tools.
PreferredTechStack.nextjsDescription: Next.js is an incredible tool with powerful out-of-the-box features. The built-in optimizations and Vercel integration make it a strong choice for modern applications.
PreferredTechStack.angularDescription: As my career has progressed, I've found myself gravitating toward opinionated frameworks like Angular. Its structured approach, dependency injection, and built-in state management make it a solid choice for enterprise-grade applications.
PreferredTechStack.nestjsDescription: I've used Express, Java/Spring, and C#/Dotnet, and NestJS really stands out. It bridges the Inversion of Control (IoC) gap while keeping everything in TypeScript, making full-stack development seamless.
PreferredTechStack.dotnetCoreDescription: .NET Core is a powerhouse for backend development. Its performance, flexibility, and strong C# ecosystem make it one of my go-to choices for building scalable, maintainable APIs. Microsoft's modern improvements have made .NET more developer-friendly than ever.
PreferredTechStack.typescriptDescription: Once you use TypeScript, it's hard to go back. It provides strong typing without getting in the way, making large codebases more maintainable and reducing runtime errors.
PreferredTechStack.ormDescription: I see the ORM vs. sprocs debate, but for most applications, ORMs are the way to go. I enjoy the fast-paced world of feature development more than shaving microseconds off queries. That said, I can work with both approaches.
PreferredTechStack.cloudDescription: I’ve worked with AWS, Azure, and GCP—each has its quirks. What I don't enjoy? On-prem. While it makes sense at scale, the developer experience is usually far worse than working in the cloud.

Projects.title: Featured Projects
Projects.subtitle: Explore my portfolio of projects that showcase my skills and creativity.
Projects.theAgilePokerDescription: As an Agile team, our scrum master continued using different agile poker applications with free trials. Agile Poker was created first to benefit the team by having a consistent tool, but also as a way to experiment with NestJS and Socket IO. This is deployed at theagilepoker.com
Projects.chronicommWebDescription: Chronicomm is a web application that allows users to connect with other patients with chronic illnesses. The app allows users to share their experiences, ask questions, and provide support to one another. The app also features a clinical trial directory to help folks better track the potential treatments available to them. I had a rough go about with Long COVID. There are slack and discord communities but using those platforms was rather limiting. I wanted to give back to the community and help others who are struggling with chronic illnesses. I built this app to help facilitate those connections and provide a space for people to share their experiences and support one another.
Projects.chronicommMobileDescription: Chronicomm mobile is the mobile companion app to Chronicomm Web.
Projects.aicodegenDescription: aicodegen was a night of hacking where I built a CLI tool to generate test code for JavaScript and TypeScript projects. It may be language agnostic, but that hasn't been tested. The premise is that you install the package, set you openai key, configure your test configurations and context files, and run the command. It will generate test code for you based on your context files and configurations. I'd really love to integrate this better with AST to create and update test files, but that is a future goal.
Projects.reactNativeFullscreenAnimationsDescripti: A simple library of full screen animations for React Native.
Projects.terraOSDescription: In 2024, I decided I needed to touch grass some more. I got my Pesticide Applicator license and started doing some lawn treatments in my spare time. I built the base version of Terra OS to help me manage my customers, schedule treatments, and manage EPA and other regulatory body compliance. I realized I basically built a SaaS product and transitioned it from a single tenant solution to multi-tenant with additional features based on lawn care owner feedback. Terra OS should be launching in April of 2025. There's a lot of great features in here and I'm excited to share it with the world.
Projects.opendorsePlatformDescription: This hosts the Opendorse flagship products. It's a web app that facilitates NIL dollars between athletes, brands, collectives, and institutions.
Projects.opendorseMobileDescription: Opendorse offers a mobile app for athletes to manage their NIL opportunities.
Projects.opendorseTeamBuilderDescription: I lead development on the Opendorse Team Builder product. This is a web app that allows athletic departments to plan the spend commitments across different sports and positions. It offers a low latency, excel-sheet like experience for power users and is integrated with our snowflake data warehouse to provide real-time proprietary data insights into the competitiveness of their offers based on perceived athlete performance.
Projects.lowesManifestDescription: A vendor that we worked with was unexpectedly sunsetting a product that our Asset Proection Team used. It was basically a document storage app relating to waste manifests and Environmental Impact Assessments. I built a React/Express/MongoDB app that mimicked the functionality of the old app and added some additional features. It was a 3 month project and the quickest a project has been taking from inception to production in the Shared Services deparatment. I lead development on this project.
Projects.lowesAPFacialRecognitionDescription: I don't remember much about this one, but the premise was to integrate facial recognition into our Asset Protection team's existing security camera system. This touched upwards of 100,000 cameras across 1,700+ stores. There was significant value to our Asset Protection team resulting in an estimated $1.2 million in asset recovery per year.
